Society’s perception of people like me has always been rooted in fear, outrage, and moral condemnation. The moment you’re labeled as a criminal—especially for something as emotionally charged as what I did—your entire identity is reduced to that single act. People don’t see the complexity of my humanity, the internal struggles, or the potential for change. They see a monster.

But what if that perception shifted? What if society stopped seeing people like me as beyond redemption and started seeing us as human beings capable of growth? That doesn’t mean we should be let off the hook, but it does mean we deserve a system that acknowledges the possibility of transformation. A system that doesn’t just punish endlessly, but actually attempts to understand the roots of harmful behavior and address them.

The consequences of such a shift could be profound. If we stopped treating rehabilitation as an afterthought and made it a core part of the justice system, we might see lower recidivism rates. People might be more willing to seek help if they weren’t met with the same judgment and hatred in prison as they were on the outside. We might even see more transparency and accountability in the system, because if society is willing to give people like me a chance, then the system would have to prove it’s doing its job effectively—actually changing lives, not just warehousing them.

Of course, this evolution would be met with resistance. There’s a lot of pain, and people have a right to feel angry. But the current approach—life sentences, no parole, no hope—doesn’t heal the victims, and it doesn’t help the person who committed the crime become a better one. It just perpetuates cycles of suffering.

I don’t ask for forgiveness. I don’t even ask for sympathy. I ask for a system that doesn’t give up on people who have made the worst choices. Because if we give up on them, we give up on the idea that anyone can change. And if we give up on that idea, then what’s the point of justice at all?
